docs.snippet: Shelley Mydans, a journalist who with her husband, the photographer Carl Mydans, covered the war in Asia in World War II and later wrote a novel based on their 21 months in a Japanese prisoner-of-war camp, died on Thursday in New Rochelle, N.Y. Sh...
docs.lead_paragraph: Shelley Mydans, a journalist who with her husband, the photographer Carl Mydans, covered the war in Asia in World War II and later wrote a novel based on their 21 months in a Japanese prisoner-of-war camp, died on Thursday in New Rochelle, N.Y. She was 86. Mrs. Mydans was the author of three novels and co-author of a nonfiction book. She and her husband were Life magazine's first photographer-reporter team to cover the war.
docs.abstract: Shelley Mydans, journalist who covered World War II and later wrote novel based on her 21 months in Japanese prisoner-of-war camp, dies at age of 86; photo (M)

headline.main: Shelley Mydans, 86, Author and Former P.O.W.

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    The United States military is slowly finding out how chaotic the war in Afghanistan can be (''One War, Differing Aims,'' military analysis, front page, Dec. 18) and is now shifting its priorities.    The Northern Alliance, which ...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The United States military is slowly finding out how chaotic the war in Afghanistan can be (''One War, Differing Aims,'' military analysis, front page, Dec. 18) and is now shifting its priorities. The Northern Alliance, which is determined to make deals with the Taliban, much to the chagrin of the United States military, should be stopped before it's too late. America must make it abundantly clear that this cannot continue.
docs.abstract: Ewart Stuger letter says US military must stop Northern Alliance from making deals with Taliban (Dec 18 article)

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    The United States military has intensified combat in Afghanistan, including the dropping of a 2,000-pound ''thermobaric'' bomb (front page, March 4). Meanwhile, the Bush administration plans to expand the war on terrorism to new ...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The United States military has intensified combat in Afghanistan, including the dropping of a 2,000-pound ''thermobaric'' bomb (front page, March 4). Meanwhile, the Bush administration plans to expand the war on terrorism to new countries. Senator Tom Daschle is right to ask for Congressional consultation (''Daschle Wants President to Tell Congress More About His Plans for War,'' news article, March 4). The country needs to pause and reflect.
docs.abstract: William Crain letter on March 4 article contends Bush adminstration should attempt diplomatic solutions before expanding military front on war on terrorism

docs.lead_paragraph: Cheney Defends Iraq Stance Addressing the Council on Foreign Relations, Vice President Dick Cheney offered a strong rebuttal to allied critics of the Bush administration's attitude toward Iraq. PAGE A8 Milosevic Seeks Witnesses Slobodan Milosevic said he would call present and past world leaders, including Bill Clinton, to testify at his war crimes trial. PAGE A3
docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

docs.snippet: Do members of Congress have any business questioning a president's military strategy in the midst of war? That was the question swirling around Capitol Hill last week. In the heat of debate, some went so far as to insinuate that any questioning of...
docs.lead_paragraph: Do members of Congress have any business questioning a president's military strategy in the midst of war? That was the question swirling around Capitol Hill last week. In the heat of debate, some went so far as to insinuate that any questioning of a wartime president is divisive and unpatriotic. What dangerous nonsense this is. Congress not only has the right to question a president's policies, but also the duty. In a war, the American people have every right to a full accounting of what their sons and daughters are fighting for and what their government expects to achieve. To question is not to accuse or to condemn. To question is to seek the truth. The less forthcoming a president is, the more Congress will have to probe for answers. Such is the current situation.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Sen Robert C Byrd says loss of American lives in Afghanistan requires that Congress question Pres Bush's wartime policies, no matter how uncomfortable questioning may be; says some insinuate that any questioning in Congress of wartime president is divisive and unpatriotic; says Congress not only has right to question president's policies, but also the duty; says Americans have every right to full accounting of what their sons and daughters are fighting for in war, and what their government expects to achieve; says to question is not to accuse or to condemn; says less forthcoming a president is, more Congress will have to probe for answers; says such is current situation with Pres Bush (M)

headline.main: Why Congress Has to Ask Questions

docs.snippet: The Public Lives profile on Wednesday, about C. Stevens Laise, a National Park Service official in Manhattan, misspelled the given name of a Confederate general he mentioned while recounting a childhood visit to a Civil War battlefield that inspir...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Public Lives profile on Wednesday, about C. Stevens Laise, a National Park Service official in Manhattan, misspelled the given name of a Confederate general he mentioned while recounting a childhood visit to a Civil War battlefield that inspired his interest in history. The general was Barnard Bee, not Bernard.
docs.abstract: Correction of March 27 Public Lives profile of C Stevens Laise, National Park Service official in Manhattan

docs.snippet: Raising hopes for an end to Sri Lanka's 17-year civil war, peace talks between the government and the island's Tamil rebels will take place in Thailand in early May, the Thai foreign minister, Dr. Surakiart Sathirathai, announced in Bangkok. Norwe...
docs.lead_paragraph: Raising hopes for an end to Sri Lanka's 17-year civil war, peace talks between the government and the island's Tamil rebels will take place in Thailand in early May, the Thai foreign minister, Dr. Surakiart Sathirathai, announced in Bangkok. Norwegian officials will mediate the talks, the first in seven years. Somini Sengupta (NYT)
docs.abstract: Peace talks set between Sri Lankan government and Tamil rebels (S)

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Peace Talks In Bangkok
